For municipalities, class designation is based on the MCA 7-1-4111. Classification of municipalities. (1) Every city having a population of 10,000 or more is a city of the first class. (2) Every city having a population of less than 10,000 and more than 5,000 is a city of the second class. (3) Every city having a population of less than 5,000 and more than 1,000 is a city of the third class. (4) Every municipal corporation having a population of less than 1,000 and more than 300 is a town.

description:
The taxable valuation is the portion (percentage) of the appraised value of any property that is subject to a property tax mill levy. Both the appraised value and the resulting taxable value are determined by periodic, appraisals conducted by the Montana Department of Revenue applying a tax rate enacted by the legislature and furnished to all units of local government as annual, certified taxable values lying within the local government’s jurisdiction. The taxable value is the basis for the local government’s mill value, which is the taxable value of the jurisdiction divided by 1,000.

The property tax burden to support municipal government spending varies widely and primarily as a function of the extent to which the property tax base includes significant commercial or industrial assets. Hence, the property tax mill levy in a rural Montana town is likely to be disproportionately higher than one might encounter in any of Montana’s large, metropolitan communities precisely because the larger communities include a substantial commercial and industrial component in their taxable valuation. In many of Montana’s smaller, rural communities the greatest share of the property tax burden is carried by single-family, residential property. More information is available at MCA 15-6-1 and MCA 15-8-1.
The general fund is used to account for all of the local government’s financial resources except those required to be accounted for in another fund.

description: Road Miles pertain to transportation routes that are "Open to Public Travel" as defined by the Montana Department of Transportation Fuel Tax Allocations program and does not represent all mileage in the state. This mileage is exclusive of the National Highway and Primary Systems. You can find more information about the Fuel Tax Allocation Program at: http://www.mdt.mt.gov/business/fueltax/allocations.shtml. Open to Public Travel is defined as a segment of road available for public use except during periods of extreme weather or emergency conditions, passable by a 2-wheel drive passenger car and open to the general public. Restrictions include; primitive trails, driveway to a single residence, field access roads, parking lots, restrictive gates, orange markings on posts, or "No Trespassing" signs (MCA 45-6-201).
Form of government refers to the legal structure that guides the governing functions. Details of the various forms are provided in the MCA 7-3-111, 112, 113, 114 and 123.

description: A local government unit without self-government powers has general powers as provided by the Montana Constitution, Article XI, Section 4. As provided by the Montana Constitution, Article XI, Section 6, a local government unit with self-government powers may exercise any power not prohibited by the constitution, law, or charter. These powers include but are not limited to the powers granted to general power governments. More information is available at MCA 7-1-1.
